The enzyme of yeasts and some bacteria exhibits about 10-fold higherk cat and K m values than those of the enzyme from animals and plants. Typically Thr-269 and Glu-267 are found in the coenzyme-binding site of yeast FALDH, but Ile-269 and Asp-267 are present in the FALDH of animals. By site-directed mutagenesis we have prepared the T269I and the D267E mutants and the D267E/T269I double mutant of Saccharomyces cerevisiae FALDH with the aim of investigating the role of these residues in the kinetics. The T269I and the D267E mutants have identical kinetic properties as compared with the wild-type enzyme, although T269I is highly unstable. In contrast, the D267E/T269I double mutant is stable and shows low K m (2.5 μm) and low k cat (285 min−1) values with S-hydroxymethylglutathione, similar to those of the human enzyme. Therefore, the simultaneous exchange at both residues is the structural basis of the two distinct FALDH kinetic types. The local structural perturbations imposed by the substitutions are suggested by molecular modeling studies. Finally, we have studied the effect of FALDH deletion and overexpression on the growth of S. cerevisiae. It is concluded that the FALDH gene is not essential but enhances the resistance against formaldehyde (0.3–1 mm). Moreover, the wild-type enzyme (with highk cat and K m) provides more resistance than the double mutant (with lowk cat and K m). glutathione-dependent formaldehyde dehydrogenase substitution of Glu for Asp-267 substitution of Ile for Thr-269 double substitution of Glu for Asp-267 and Ile for Thr-269 inhibition constant for NADH dissociation constant for NAD+ alcohol dehydrogenase S-hydroxymethylglutathione 3-acetylpyridine adenine dinucleotide bovine serum albumin dithiothreitol Formaldehyde is a highly reactive compound that is present in the environment as a result of natural processes and human industrial activity. Moreover, formaldehyde is also generated endogenously by several metabolic pathways (1Fujiwara K. Okamuraa-Ikeda K. Motokawa Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 10664-10668Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 2Porter D.H. Cook R.J. Wagner C. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1985; 243: 396-407Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 3Waydhas C. Weigl K. Sies H. Eur. J. Biochem. 1978; 89: 143-150Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar, 4Shara M.A. Dickson P.H. Bagchi D. Stohss S.J. J. Chromatogr. 1992; 576: 221-233Crossref PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar, 5Yu P.H. Lai C.-T. Zuo D.-M. Neurochem. Res. 1997; 22: 615-620Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). In humans the level of formaldehyde in blood has been estimated as 0.46–2.81 μm (6Hallier E. Schröder K.R. Asmuth K. Dommermuth A. Aust B. Goergens H.W. Arch. Toxicol. 1994; 68: 423-427Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). The elimination of formaldehyde in eukaryotic cells is mainly carried out by glutathione-dependent formaldehyde dehydrogenase (FALDH)1 (7Koivusalo M. Baumann M. Uotila L. FEBS Lett. 1989; 257: 105-109Crossref PubMed Scopus (291) Google Scholar). Formaldehyde reacts spontaneously with glutathione (GSH) to form theS-hydroxymethylglutathione (S-HMGSH) adduct which, in the presence of NAD+, is oxidized toS-formylglutathione by FALDH (8Uotila L. Koivusalo M. J. Biol. Chem. 1974; 249: 7653-7663Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar).S-Formylglutathione is irreversibly hydrolyzed byS-formylglutathione hydrolase to formate and GSH (8Uotila L. Koivusalo M. J. Biol. Chem. 1974; 249: 7653-7663Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In addition to the glutathione-dependent formaldehyde dehydrogenase activity, FALDH is also active with long chain alcohols, particularly with ω-hydroxylated fatty acids such as 12-hydroxydodecanoic acid (9Parés X. Vallee B.L. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1981; 98: 122-130Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar, 10Wagner F.W. Parés X. Holmquist B. Vallee B.L. Biochemistry. 1984; 23: 2193-2199Crossref PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar, 11Giri P.R. Linnoila M. O'Neill J.B. Goldman D. Brain Res. 1989; 481: 131-141Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 12Moulis J.-M. Holmquist B. Vallee B.L. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 5743-5749Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). Interestingly FALDH is capable of catalyzing efficiently the NADH-dependent degradation ofS-nitrosoglutathione derived from the glutathione nitrosation by nitric oxide (13Jensen D.E. Belka G.K. Du Bois G.C. Biochem. J. 1998; 331: 659-668Crossref PubMed Scopus (233) Google Scholar). FALDH is a dimeric enzyme with subunits of 40 kDa, containing two zinc atoms per subunit, and it appears to be ubiquitous in eukaryotic organisms (14Uotila L. Koivusalo M. Dolphin D. Poulson R. Avramovic O. Coenzymes and Cofactors. 3. John Wiley and Sons, Inc., New York1989: 517-551Google Scholar). FALDH is a member of the medium chain alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) family, and it represents the ADH class (class III) most closely related to the ancestral line that originated by successive gene duplications the ADH enzymes now found in animals and plants (15Jörnvall H. Shafqat J. El-Ahmad M. Hjelmqvist L. Persson B. Danielsson O. Adv. Exp. Med. Biol. 1997; 414: 281-289Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that human FALDH shares a similar overall structure with the known class I ADH three-dimensional structures (16Yang Z.-N. Bosron W.F. Hurley T.D. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 265: 330-343Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). Although there is a high degree of sequence identity (63%) between the human and yeast enzyme, the K m andk cat values for the Saccharomyces cerevisiae enzyme (20 μm and 3100 min−1, respectively) are significantly higher than those for the human FALDH (4 μm and 200 min−1) (17Fernández M.R. Biosca J.A. Norin A. Jörnvall H. Parés X. FEBS Lett. 1995; 370: 23-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, 18Holmquist B. Vallee B.L. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1991; 178: 1371-1377Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar). In general, K m values forS-HMGSH are higher for all yeast and bacterial FALDH known (25–260 μm) (14Uotila L. Koivusalo M. Dolphin D. Poulson R. Avramovic O. Coenzymes and Cofactors. 3. John Wiley and Sons, Inc., New York1989: 517-551Google Scholar, 19Allais J.J. Louktibi A. Baratti J. Agric. Biol. Chem. 1983; 47: 1509-1516Crossref Scopus (1) Google Scholar, 20Gultheil W.G. Holmquist B. Vallee B. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 475-481Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar) than for the animal and plant FALDH (4–9 μm) (7Koivusalo M. Baumann M. Uotila L. FEBS Lett. 1989; 257: 105-109Crossref PubMed Scopus (291) Google Scholar, 18Holmquist B. Vallee B.L. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1991; 178: 1371-1377Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar, 21Danielsson O. Atrian S. Luque T. Hjelmqvist L. Gonzàlez-Duarte R. Jörnvall H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 4980-4984Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar, 22Fernández M.R. Jörnvall H. Moreno A. Kaiser R. Parés X. FEBS Lett. 1993; 328: 235-238Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar, 23Shafqat J. El-Ahmad M. Danielsson O. Martı́nez M.C. Persson B. Parés X. Jörnvall H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 5595-5599Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). Therefore, the existence of two FALDH kinetic types is apparent as follows: the microorganism type with high K m and k catvalues, and the multicellular organism type with both lowK m and k cat values. Here we report site-directed mutagenesis performed on the S. cerevisiae enzyme in order to identify residues responsible for the different kinetic characteristics of the two distinct FALDH types. In addition, we study the effect of FALDH deletion and overexpression on the growth of S. cerevisiae with the aim of elucidating the metabolic importance of FALDH in yeast. Yeast nitrogen base without amino acids (Wickerham formula) was purchased from U. S. Biochemical Corp. Bacto-agar was from Difco. Zymolyase-100T was from ICN Biomedicals. β-NAD+ (grade III), NADH, glutathione, paraformaldehyde, glass beads (0.4–0.6 mm), DEAE-Sepharose, glucose, and medium supplements (amino acids, adenine hemisulfate, and uracil) were from Sigma. Blue-Sepharose CL-6B, Superdex 200 HR 10/30, PD10 columns, PhastGel native buffer strips, and Native PhastGels were supplied by Amersham Pharmacia Biotech. A 20% solution of [2H2]formaldehyde (98% isotopic enrichment) in 2H2O was obtained from Medical Isotopes Inc. Protein-pack Q8 HR was from Waters. Hydroxyapatite Bio-Gel HT, sodium dodecyl sulfate, acrylamide, bisacrylamide, and goat anti-rabbit IgG conjugated with alkaline phosphatase were from Bio-Rad. Vent DNA polymerase was from New England Biolabs. Selex 20 was from Schleicher & Schüell. The deletion of the FALDHgene (initially named SFA1 (24Wehner E.P. Rao E. Brendel M. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1993; 237: 351-358Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar), open reading frame nameYDL168W) was carried out by one-step gene replacement (25Rothstein R.J. Methods Enzymol. 1983; 101: 202-211Crossref PubMed Scopus (2033) Google Scholar) with the URA3 gene. Briefly, aPstI/EcoRI fragment containing the coding and flanking regions of FALDH was subcloned in the pBR322 vector, and after removing the coding region of FALDH by digestion with ScaI, the URA3 gene was inserted. The URA3 gene was obtained by digesting the YDp-U vector (26Berben G. Dumont J. Gilliquet V. Bolle P.A. Hilger F. Yeast. 1991; 7: 475-477Crossref PubMed Scopus (317) Google Scholar) with BamHI and was subcloned into the ScaI site of the FALDH construct, after making blunt ends. This construct was digested with SacI/EcoRI, resulting in a lineal fragment containing the URA3 gene flanked by homologous regions to the 5′ and 3′ regions of the FALDHgene. This fragment was introduced into the yeast W303D S. cerevisiae (MAT a/MAT ∝ ade2-1/ade2-1 his 3-11,15/his 3-11,15 leu2-3,112/leu2-3,112 trp1-1/trp1-1 ura3-1/ura3-1 can1-100/can1-100) by the lithium acetate method (27Becker D.M. Lundbad V. Ausubel F. Brent R. Kingston R.E. Moore D.D. Seidman J.G. Smith J.A. Struhl K. Current Protocols in Molecular Biology. 2. John Wiley and Sons, Inc., New York1994: 13.7.1-13.7.2Google Scholar), and after homologous recombination, the coding region of FALDH was substituted by the URA3 gene. The yeast cells that had incorporated URA3 were selected by growing in Wikerham's medium supplemented for all auxotrophs except for uracil. The transformed yeast was then induced to sporulate by growing during 5 days in sporulation medium (1% potassium acetate, 0.1% bacto-yeast extract, 0.05% glucose, 2% bacto-agar) supplemented for auxotrophs. The sporulated culture was digested with zymolyase-100T, and 8 asci were dissected by using a micromanipulator under a dissecting microscope. The spores were allowed to germinate into a YPD plate (1% bacto-yeast extract, 2% bacto-peptone, 2% glucose, and 2% bacto-agar) and formed colonies in 2–3 days after dissection. TheURA3 phenotype was scored by replica plating onto Wikerham's medium without uracil. The deletion of the FALDHgene in several spores was confirmed by Southern blotting of genomic DNA digested with NcoI/PstI, and hybridized with the fragment ClaI/NcoI of FALDHlabeled with [α-32P]dCTP (45Brown T. Ausubel F. Brent R. Kingston R.E. Moore D.D. Seidman J.G. Smith J.A. Struhl K. Current Protocols in Molecular Biology. 1. John Wiley and Sons, Inc., New York1993: 2.9.1-2.10.16Google Scholar). One colony derived from one of these spores was chosen as the FALDH null mutant strain (FALDH−). The FALDHgene from X2180 S. cerevisiae (17Fernández M.R. Biosca J.A. Norin A. Jörnvall H. Parés X. FEBS Lett. 1995; 370: 23-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar) was digested byNcoI/ClaI, subcloned into the Yeplac181 vector (FALDH-Yeplac181) (28Gietz R.D. Sugino A. Gene (Amst.). 1988; 74: 527-534Crossref PubMed Scopus (2528) Google Scholar), and expressed under its own promotor in the yeast FALDH−. Yeast was grown until stationary phase in 2 liters of supplemented Wikerham's medium without leucine. Yeast cells were sedimented by centrifugation, and they were disrupted in 10 mm Tris-HCl, 0.5 mm DTT, pH 7.5, with 0.5-mm diameter glass-beads in a bead-beater (Biospec Products, Inc.). The lysate was applied to a DEAE-Sepharose column (2 × 32 cm) equilibrated with the previous buffer. After washing with the same buffer, the enzyme was eluted with a linear gradient from 0 to 0.18m NaCl in 300 ml of buffer. The active fractions were pooled, concentrated, and dialyzed against 10 mm sodium phosphate, 0.5 mm DTT, pH 6.8, and applied to a hydroxyapatite column (1.5 × 10 cm). The enzyme was eluted with a linear gradient from 10 to 400 mm sodium phosphate, 0.5 mm DTT, pH 6.8, in 200 ml. Active fractions were concentrated, dialyzed against 10 mm Tris-HCl, 0.5 mm DTT, pH 7.5, and applied to a Blue-Sepharose column (1 × 27 cm). After washing with the buffer, the enzyme was eluted with a linear gradient of NADH from 0 to 750 μm in 300 ml of buffer. The purified FALDH was concentrated and dialyzed against 100 mm Tris-HCl, 0.5 mm DTT, pH 7.5, and stored at −80 °C. Protein was quantified by the method of Bradford (29Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (217507) Google Scholar), using bovine serum albumin as a standard. Mutations (D267E, T269I, and D267E/T269I) were introduced by sequential steps of polymerase chain reaction amplification using two mutagenic primers (B and C) and two external primers, one flanking a BglII site and another flanking a BclI site (A and D, respectively) (46Cormack B. Ausubel F. Brent R. Kingston R.E. Moore D.D. Seidman J.G. Smith J.A. Struhl K. Current Protocols in Molecular Biology. 2. John Wiley and Sons, Inc., New York1997: 8.5.1-8.5.10Google Scholar). TheFALDH gene was cloned into pBluescript SK(+) (FALDH-pBluescript). For insertion of T269I and D267E/T269I mutations, the mutagenic primers were designed to be degenerated with respect to the mutation D267E. Thus 100% of amplified product would incorporate mutation T269I but only one-half would incorporate also the mutation D267E. In a first round one amplification was performed with primer A, 5′-GTCTTTAATTAAACCGCCCATTTCAG-3′, and the mutagenic primer B, 5′-TTTGA(A/C)TGTATTGGTAATACCAAAATTATGAG-3′, and a second amplification with the mutagenic primer C, 5′-ACCAATACA(G/T)TCAAAAGTAAAATCCAG-3′, and primer D, 5′-ATCCAGCTGGACTTTTCCCTTGCGTTCTGG-3′, both with 100 ngFALDH-pBluescript as a template, 1 μm each primer, 200 μm each dNTP, 3 mmMgSO4, and 1 unit of Vent DNA polymerase (where boldface letters indicate the mutations introduced). Amplifications were performed with 30 cycles of 1 min at 95 °C, 1 min at 54.9 °C, and 40 s at 72 °C. In a second round the products from the first round were used as templates together with the primers A and D in 30 amplification cycles of 1 min at 95 °C, 1 min at 56.3 °C, and 51 s at 72 °C. The amplification product was then digested withBglII and BclI and cloned intoFALDH-pBluescript, previously digested with the same restriction enzymes, substituting the wild-type fragment with the mutagenized fragment. Since the introduction of T269I mutation resulted in the loss of a BsrI site, this enzyme was used to identify the clones that incorporated the mutation. The mutagenizedFALDH gene was then digested withNcoI/ClaI, subcloned into the Yeplac181 vector, and expressed in the same way as the wild-type enzyme. To insert the mutation D267E, the mutagenic primers B′, 5′-TTTGAATGTACTGGTAATACCAAAATTATG-3′, and C′, 5′-ACCAGTACATTCAAAAGTAAAATCTAGACC-3′, were used. The primer C′ was designed in order to insert not only mutation D267E but also a silent mutation that creates a newXbaI restriction site (underlined). In the first round two amplifications were performed, one with primers A and B′ and another with primers C′ and D, both with 100 ng ofFALDH-pBluescript as a template, 1 μm of each primer, 200 μm of each dNTP, 3 mmMgSO4, and 1 unit of Vent DNA polymerase. Amplifications were performed with 30 amplification cycles of 1 min at 95 °C, 1 min at 53.8 °C, and 1 min at 72 °C. In a second round the products from the first round were used as templates together with primers A and D in 30 amplification cycles of 1 min at 95 °C, 1 min at 54.9 °C, and 40 s at 72 °C. The amplification product was digested withBglII/BclI and subcloned intoFALDH-Yeplac181 previously digested with the same restriction enzymes, substituting the wild-type fragment between these restriction sites with the mutagenized fragment. The presence of mutation and the correct fragment orientation was confirmed by digestion with XbaI. All mutated DNA was completely sequenced, prior to expression, to ensure that no unwanted mutations were present. The mutant enzymes were expressed and purified using a similar procedure as the one described for the wild-type enzyme with some differences. For the T269I mutant, an unstable enzyme, purification was performed with yeast grown to exponential phase (in order to avoid the high protease levels found in the stationary phase), and all steps were carried out in presence of 30% glycerol and protease inhibitors (1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 1 mmbenzamidine, and 1 μg/ml pepstatin A). For the D267E/T269I enzyme, due to the low activity detected in the initial lysate, it was necessary to start the purification with 30 liters of culture that were grown in a bioreactor (Biostat-UD, B. Braun Biotech), and the subsequent chromatographic steps were scaled up accordingly. Enzyme activity was determined spectrophotometrically at 25 °C by monitoring the production of NADH at 340 nm (ε340 = 6.22 mm−1cm−1) with a Hewlett-Packard 8452A diode array spectrophotometer. One unit of activity corresponds to 1 μmol of NAD(H) formed per min. Alcohol oxidation was measured with 2.4 mm NAD+ in 0.1 m glycine/NaOH, pH 10. Formaldehyde dehydrogenase activity was measured in 0.1m sodium phosphate, pH 8.0, with S-HMGSH (formed by mixing formaldehyde and glutathione) (7Koivusalo M. Baumann M. Uotila L. FEBS Lett. 1989; 257: 105-109Crossref PubMed Scopus (291) Google Scholar). The standard assay mixture contained 1 mm formaldehyde, 1 mm glutathione, 2.4 mm NAD+ in 0.1 m sodium phosphate, pH 8.0. For the kinetic studies concentration ofS-HMGSH was established by adjusting the total concentrations of glutathione and formaldehyde in order to maintain the concentration of free glutathione at 1 mm, on the basis of the dissociation constant of S-HMGSH. Dissociation constant values of 1.5 mm (7Koivusalo M. Baumann M. Uotila L. FEBS Lett. 1989; 257: 105-109Crossref PubMed Scopus (291) Google Scholar) and 1.3 mm (30Pourmotabbed T. Shih M.J. Creighton D.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 17384-17388Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) were used for diprotio- and S-hydroxy-[2H2]methylglutathione, respectively. Formaldehyde (20%) was obtained by hydrolysis of paraformaldehyde during 16 h at 100 °C. Stock solutions of formaldehyde were standardized as reported (17Fernández M.R. Biosca J.A. Norin A. Jörnvall H. Parés X. FEBS Lett. 1995; 370: 23-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). Kinetic constants were calculated by using the non-linear regression program Enzfitter (Elsevier Biosoft). K ia andK i (NADH) values were calculated with the COMP program (31Cleland W.W. Methods Enzymol. 1979; 189: 436-441Google Scholar). Values are expressed as the mean of at least three separate experiments. Native gel electrophoresis was performed in a PhastSystem instrument (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) using the PhastGel homogeneous 12.5% polyacrylamide gels with PhastGel native buffer strips and subsequent silver staining. For Western blot analysis, proteins were separated by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis as described (32Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (207521) Google Scholar) and subsequently transferred to a polypropylene membrane (Selex 20) by electroblotting in 25 mm Tris, 200 mm glycine, pH 8.5, containing 20% methanol. The membrane was blocked against nonspecific protein binding by overnight treatment in Tris-buffered saline (Tris/NaCl) containing 10 mmTris/HCl, 150 mm NaCl, pH 8.0, with the addition of 1% (w/v) bovine serum albumin (BSA). The membrane was then incubated for 2 h with rabbit anti-(rat class III ADH) antiserum diluted 1:1000 in Tris/NaCl/BSA, washed in Tris/NaCl/BSA for 5 min, incubated for 1.5 h with goat anti-(rabbit IgG) alkaline phosphatase-conjugated, and washed five times in Tris/NaCl/BSA for 5 min each time. The membrane was further developed by incubation in 100 mmTris-HCl, 100 mm NaCl, 5 mm MgCl2, pH 9.5, containing 16.5% (w/v) 5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl phosphate and 0.33% (w/v) nitro blue tetrazolium. When sufficiently developed, the reaction was stopped by washing in water. A three-dimensional model of the 260–280-residue region, in the coenzyme binding domain of yeast formaldehyde dehydrogenase, was obtained by adopting its amino acid sequence into the known fold of the human FALDH subunit (16Yang Z.-N. Bosron W.F. Hurley T.D. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 265: 330-343Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar), using the software package ICM (version 2.7, Molsoft LLC, Metuchen, NJ). We assumed a similar general conformation of this region for the yeast and human enzymes, based on the high sequence similarity (87%) and on the known well conserved structure of the Rossman fold. In the first step of model building, tethers were imposed between the yeast enzyme residues 260–265, 275–280, and those of the human FALDH structure, and they were then minimized. This step was done to get the same backbone structure in the flanking residues of this region. Two levels of freedom were adopted. For residues 260–265 and 275–280, only the side chain angles (χ i) were free, whereas main chain angles, ϕ and ψ, were kept fixed in order to preserve the whole loop shape (or avoiding any backbone deviation). For residues 266–274, main chain angles (ϕ and ψ) and side chain angles (χ i) were allowed to reach an optimal conformation. After iterative combined geometry and energy optimization and adjustments of polar hydrogen positions, the whole 260–280-residue region was subject for a biased Monte Carlo procedure (33Abagyan R.A. Totrov M.M. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 235: 983-1002Crossref PubMed Scopus (819) Google Scholar) (1000 iterations for every Monte Carlo step and 5 × 106 total steps). The temperature of the simulation was 1500 K, in order to avoid any local minimum energy. The same procedure was used with each mutant studied. The calculations were performed in a Silicon Graphics Indigo 2 R10000 workstation. Yeast FALDH must exhibit structural differences from the group of animal and plant FALDHs, which should explain its distinct kinetic properties. Comparison of the yeast (S. cerevisiaeand Candida maltosa) and animal and plant FALDH sequences shows that, in general, those residues that participate in the substrate binding, coenzyme binding, and subunit-subunit interactions are conserved. There is one relevant change in the coenzyme-binding pocket: a Thr at position 269 in yeast instead of Ile found in the human enzyme, used as an example of the animal and plant FALDH type. The presence of a polar residue at position 269 may affect coenzyme binding and could contribute to the kinetic differences between the human and yeast FALDH. In order to check for this hypothesis the residue Thr-269 in S. cerevisiae FALDH was changed to Ile (T269I mutant). The comparison between the FALDH primary structures also revealed that the presence of Thr at position 269 was associated with Asp at position 267 in yeast, whereas the presence of Ile at position 269 was associated with Glu at position 267 in human as well as in all animal and plant FALDHs. Thus, we also decided to change Asp-267 to Glu (D267E mutation) and the double mutation Asp-267 to Glu and Thr-269 to Ile (D267E/T269I). Wild-type and mutant FALDHs were expressed in the FALDH− yeast, and the stability of each protein was analyzed prior to its purification. The wild-type enzyme did not lose any activity in the crude extract after 3 days at 4 °C, and it was purified to homogeneity in three chromatographic steps. From 25 g of yeast cells, 240 μg of pure enzyme were obtained with a 24% yield and a specific activity of 32 units/mg. The D267E mutant was also stable in the crude extract, and it was purified to homogeneity with an 11% yield and a specific activity of 25 units/mg. From 37 g of yeast, 44 μg of homogeneous protein were obtained. In contrast, the T269I mutant showed a complete inactivation in the crude extract, after less than 24 h at 4 °C. The loss of activity was correlated with the loss of FALDH protein by Western blot analysis (not shown), suggesting digestion by proteases. Different agents for stabilizing the T269I enzyme were tested. Thus, after 12 h at 4 °C, activity was 87% of the initial value in the presence of 1 mm NAD+, 13% in the presence of protease inhibitors, and 90% in the presence of 30% glycerol. This unstable protein was, therefore, purified to homogeneity in the presence of 30% glycerol and protease inhibitors in all chromatographic steps. From 37 g of yeast, 410 μg of purified enzyme were obtained with a 31% yield and a specific activity of 29 units/mg. The NAD+ (2.4 mm) added to the enzymatic assay prevented the inactivation during the activity determination in the absence of glycerol. After purification, the T269I mutant was still unstable. Thus, when glycerol concentration was reduced from 30 to 10%, there was an immediate decrease in FALDH activity by 50%, and when glycerol was reduced to 0.6% the mutant enzyme was completely inactivated. The T269I mutant did not change its activity when it was incubated in the presence of 30% glycerol and 1 mm EDTA, but it lost completely its activity in 10% glycerol plus 1 mm EDTA. In contrast, the wild-type enzyme kept 100% activity in 1 mmEDTA, even in the absence of glycerol. Analysis by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, electroblotting, and immunodetection of the inactivated mutant enzyme showed a single band with the same mobility and intensity than that of the active enzyme, which demonstrates absence of protein degradation (not shown). Native polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis showed that the samples that conserved activity exhibited a band around 80 kDa, at the same level to that of the wild-type enzyme (Fig. 1). However a smear was detected in all T269I samples with activity, possibly indicating partial unfolding and aggregation of the protein while the sample was entering the polyacrylamide gel, due to glycerol dilution. On the other hand, neither the T269I sample inactivated by incubation in EDTA with 10% glycerol, nor the denatured wild-type enzyme showed any band (Fig. 1). This could be due to protein aggregation in either case that did not allow the protein to penetrate the gel. Taken together, these data indicate that mutant T269I was highly unstable because it rapidly unfolded in the absence of a suitable concentration of stabilizing agents. Moreover, it was also more sensitive to the zinc chelating effect of EDTA. Surprisingly, the addition of a single methylene group in the side chain of residue 267 stabilized the T269I enzyme. Thus, the D267E/T269I double mutant showed no loss of activity after 3 days at 4 °C. From 393 g of yeast, 16 mg of D267E/T269I protein were obtained with a final yield of 41% and a specific activity of 2.9 units/mg. The steady-state kinetic properties of D267E and T269I mutants are similar to those of the wild-type enzyme (Table I). Interestingly, the D267E/T269I double mutation strongly affects the kinetic parameters. Thus, the double mutant exhibitsk cat and K m values forS-HMGSH approximately 11-fold lower and 8-fold lower, respectively, than those of the wild-type enzyme. Thek cat and K m also decreased approximately 5- and 12-fold, respectively, for 12-hydroxydodecanoic acid (not shown). As a result of the kinetic changes, the D267E/T269I mutant shows kinetic characteristics similar to those of the human and in general to those of the all animal and plant FA
